Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Integrating Spatial Analysis into Long Term Research

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration: The SPatial Archaeometry Research Collaborations (SPARC) Program promotes the use of spatial analysis, 3D modeling, and remote sensing technologies in archaeological research projects. The things archaeologists study—from artifacts to sites to landscapes—almost always have spatial components that are essential to understanding cultural processes. Digital museums allow for morphometric analyses of remote, fragile, and/or priceless artifacts; geophysical investigations help pinpoint subsurface features such as houses that save time and money during excavation; the remote sensing technique LiDAR (Light Detection and Ranging) identifies natural and anthropogenic landscapes such as ancient roads through impediments like vegetation cover. Today, the increasing availability and sophistication of digital technologies is not merely generating new data but is facilitating entirely novel means of engaging with the archaeological record. However, the high costs of instrumentation and software, combined with the expertise they require, create a hurdle for many archaeologists who aim to deploy geospatial technologies in research projects. Through a competitive, peer-reviewed application process, SPARC facilitates collaborations between archaeologists interested in adding a digital component to their research with SPARC institutions, who leverage the technological infrastructure of instrumentation, software, and expertise of faculty and technical staff at the University of Arkansas' Center for Advanced Spatial Technologies, Dartmouth College’s Spatial Archaeometry Lab, and the University of Glasgow. Since 2013, SPARC has supported 35 collaborative projects involving 73 PIs and co-PIs from 46 different institutions for research in over 20 countries. SPARC has a strong track record of supporting women and early-career researchers, providing external funding and publishing opportunities essential to developing competitive careers, and for researchers located at public universities and non-profits. Online seminars and workshops, student training opportunities, leadership in professional organizations, methodological innovations, and new grant awards all stem from SPARC research.<br/><br/>The SPARC Program's goals are to: enhance the research productivity of archaeological projects by making geospatial technologies available to researchers who would not otherwise have access to the tools or skills needed to collect and analyze these data; generate high-value, efficient archaeological data by participating in fieldwork and analytical projects; provide training opportunities for students and professionals seeking to use geospatial techniques; promote the development of new geospatial applications in archaeology and their visibility to the broader community; and support good practice in archiving and publication of digital data. SPARC offers direct support to archaeological projects through awards in three categories—Fieldwork (on-site data collection), Data & Analytics (preparation, processing, and analysis), and Publication (presentation, publication, and archiving)—that utilize a wide-ranging set of methods including high-performance computing, surface reconstruction and morphometric analysis, volumetric 3D imaging, near-surface geophysics, aerial remote sensing and survey (e.g. “drones”), geodetic positioning and topographic survey, and 3D visualization. SPARC strives to build a program that is increasingly visible - attracting top research projects; efficient - as project staff build on their experience; high impact - as pilot projects build skills in research teams around the world; and innovative - with broader collaborations leading to significant methodological advancements.<br/><br/>This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The award, 'Collaborative Research: Integrating Spatial Analysis into Long Term Research,' helped fund the Spatial Archaeometry Research Collaborations (SPARC) Program. The overarching goal of the SPARC is to expand access to and the use of geospatial methods in archaeology, recognizing that these are essential methods for modern research but that access to technical skills, equipment, and practitioners remains limited. SPARC is a collaboration between the Center for Advanced Spatial Technologies at University of Arkansas, the Spatial Archaeometry Research Collaborations Laboratory at Dartmouth College, and the Department of Archaeology at University of Glasgow. This Public Outcomes Report outlines activities for CAST and Glasgow.

SPARC's goals are to:

  • enhancing productivity of archaeological projects by making geospatial technologies available to researchers who would not otherwise have access to the tools or skills required;
  • directly generating high value archaeological data by participating in fieldwork and analytical projects to efficiently collect and analyze geospatial data;
  • providing training opportunities for students and professionals seeking to use geospatial techniques in their own research;
  • promoting the development of new geospatial methods and applications in archaeology and the visibility of these innovations in the broader archaeological community; and 
  • supporting good practice and innovation in archiving and publication of digital data.

Since 2013, SPARC has supported 39 projects involving 81 PIs (Principal Investigators) and co-PIs from 53 institutions, resulting in 32 publications, 31+ presentations, over $1.3 million in new grants, 9 websites, and free online educational materials. This 2020-2021 SPARC cycle supported two new projects and two continuing projects for CAST/Glasgow:

  • Digital Storytelling: The Landscape of Sport at the Granada Japanese American Relocation Center, on a publicly-oriented website about life in a WWII Japanese-American internment camp in Colorado;
  • Quantifying pastoralist niche construction on southwest Madagascar using multi-sensor remote sensing (1600 ? Present), on satellite imagery evaluations to discern human impacts on ecologically-sensitive environments;
  • Geophysical Investigations of 9th- to 14th-century AD Occupation Mounds in the Basanga Region of Western Zambia: Research at Mwanamaimpa, on locating precolonial African cities using non-destructive techniques;
  • Mapping Chacoan Roads in SE Utah, on documenting ancient Native American landscapes through aerial LiDAR survey.

Full descriptions of these projects and more general information about the SPARC Program, including research outcomes and their final reports, can be found at https://sparc.cast.uark.edu/.

Additional activities included:

  • Open-access publication of 1960's satellite imagery Mali, to assess preservation needs around the UNESCO site of Jenne-Jeno via the CORONA Atlas (https://corona.cast.uark.edu/).
  • A new set of open-access teaching materials, 'The Basics of Creating Digital Archaeological Reconstructions: A SPARC Teaching Resource,' which over the course of five exercises for college students showcases the value of archived spatial data.

Intellectual Merit

SPARC focuses on spatial archaeometry: the application of scientific techniques to measure properties of archaeological materials at all spatial scales, from artifacts to features such as buildings, to whole archaeological sites and ancient landscapes. SPARC strives to build a program that is increasingly visible-capable of attracting top research projects; efficient-as project staff build on their experience carrying out a variety of collaboration types, and by increasing the ability of our projects to conduct targeted research; high impact-as pilot projects build skills in research teams and the results of small scale projects supported through SPARC awards are integrated into larger research programs; and innovative-as broader collaborations have the potential to lead to significant methodological advancements. SPARC prioritizes advances in software, imagery, and equipment such as drones that improve the ability to acquire, analyze, and visualize spatial data. For example, the Grenada SPARC project used emerging digital storytelling techniques to merge drone imagery and archaeological artifacts with oral histories and historical materials and present an engaging digital story about Japanese-American history. In the Madagascar project, SPARC worked through technical imagery and seasonality issues to prepare collaborators for 'fusing' multiple satellite images together to understand human-environmental impacts in a critically endangered biodiversity hotspot.

Broader Impacts

The increasing availability and sophistication of geospatial technologies is not merely generating new data but is facilitating entirely novel means of exploring the human past. Spatial archaeometric techniques can also save archaeologists (and taxpayers) money, through providing a proven collaborative model that increases and democratizes access to a variety of specialist skills and technologies.

SPARC uses its research results to provide educational resources for archaeologists (and archaeology enthusiasts), found at https://github.com/castuofa/sparc_teaching. In this cycle, SPARC developed a second open-source (free) teaching resource about the 3D digital reconstruction of archaeological sites.

SPARC further provides training and research opportunities for university students and professionals. This cycle, two undergraduates, six graduate students, and six professionals participated in training activities, and four PhD students (from University of Arkansas and Pennsylvania State University) participated in research projects.

SPARC also communicates its results to interested publics, most recently through an open-access article in The SAA Archaeological Record, the magazine for the flagship American archaeological professional organization: http://onlinedigeditions.com/publication/?i=690748&p=28&pp=1&view=issueViewer.
